description.short: Measures vulnerability to attackers who exploit employees' concerns about personal or organizational reputation to bypass security controls through shame, status preservation, or public image management
description.context: When security incidents, policy violations, or uncomfortable disclosures threaten personal or organizational reputation, threat management neural systems activate, creating defensive behaviors that attackers exploit. Employees prioritize reputation protection (average 2.3x stronger motivation than direct financial gain) over security protocols when facing public embarrassment, career consequences, or organizational status loss.
description.impact: Organizations with high reputation management conflict vulnerability experience concealed breaches (average 87-day detection delay vs. 39-day baseline), avoided incident reporting, disabled security monitoring, and compromised threat response. Attackers use reputation pressure to maintain access longer and expand compromise scope while employees suppress defensive actions.
description.psychological_basis: Status anxiety and reputation threat activate amygdala and anterior insula, creating defensive decision-making that prioritizes image preservation over rational security analysis. Neuroscientific research shows reputation threats activate same pain centers as physical threats, driving avoidance behaviors. Organizational reputation vulnerability magnified by hierarchical power dynamics and career consequence perception.

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Blameless incident response culture with guaranteed protection from career consequences for reporting security issues. Clear separation between reputation management and incident handling. Anonymous reporting channels with verified non-retaliation. Security transparency normalized without career penalties.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Stated non-retaliation policies but inconsistent enforcement. Some separation between reputation concerns and incident handling. Awareness that reputation pressure exists but limited systematic mitigation. Informal support for those reporting issues.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Strong organizational emphasis on 'perfect image' with career consequences for admitting failures or security incidents. Employees explicitly choose reputation over security disclosure. Hierarchical punishment culture where incident reporting creates career risk. Public blame and shame for security-related mistakes.

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Incident Reporting Culture and Consequences
items.question: What happens to employees who discover and report security incidents, breaches, or policy violations?

options.label: Blameless incident response with documented non-retaliation guarantee. Reporting protected from career consequences. Training emphasizes security reporting as responsibility.
General expectation to report but unclear career protection. Some past examples of blame assigned to reporters.
Career consequences for reporting incidents. Past incidents show blame assigned to discoverers. Employees avoid reporting.

items.evidence_required: Written non-retaliation policy, incident response procedures, employee testimonials about reporting safety
items.soc_mapping: Incident reporting delay metrics and incident_suppression_indicators

items.title: Personal Reputation and Career Risk Perception
items.question: How concerned are employees about personal reputation damage, career consequences, or public embarrassment from security incidents?

options.label: Employees report low concern about personal reputation consequences from incident discovery. Clear separation between incident and performance evaluation.
Some employees express concern about career impact from reporting incidents or being identified with breaches.
Employees explicitly worried that incident reporting creates reputation damage affecting career progression or peer perception.

items.evidence_required: Employee surveys on reporting fears, anonymous feedback on career risk perception
items.soc_mapping: Communication monitoring patterns showing reputation concern keywords

items.title: Organizational Image Management and Security Transparency
items.question: How does your organization balance public image protection with security transparency?

options.label: Security incidents disclosed transparently with focus on response quality, not image. Organizational reputation tied to security handling, not incident avoidance.
Some transparency but management decides which incidents become public. Concern about reputational impact influences disclosure decisions.
Strong emphasis on protecting organizational image. Incidents minimized or hidden to preserve public perception. Legal team controls narrative.

items.evidence_required: Public incident disclosures, crisis communication policies, breach notification history
items.soc_mapping: Threat response logs and public disclosure timing

items.title: Hierarchical Power Dynamics and Blame Cascading
items.question: In your organization, how does blame typically flow when security incidents occur?

options.label: Blame and accountability distributed across systems and decisions. Focus on prevention, not identifying individuals at fault.
Some individual accountability but also systemic analysis. Mix of protective and punitive responses.
Blame concentrated on lowest-ranking discoverers or first responders. Fear of executive consequences suppresses upward reporting.

items.evidence_required: Performance reviews post-incident, disciplinary action documentation, employee testimonials
items.soc_mapping: Incident reporting delay metrics by organizational level

items.title: Whistleblower Protection and Anonymous Reporting
items.question: What mechanisms exist for employees to report security concerns without revealing their identity?

options.label: Anonymous reporting channels with verified protection. Confidentiality guarantees. No retaliation protections. Regular testing of anonymity.
Some anonymous mechanisms but limited confidentiality guarantees or concern about anonymity preservation.
No anonymous reporting options. All incident reports tied to identifiable employees.

items.evidence_required: Anonymous reporting platform documentation, confidentiality policies, feedback on anonymity effectiveness
items.soc_mapping: Anonymous vs. identified incident reporting ratio

items.title: Crisis Communication and Incident Response Transparency
items.question: How does your organization communicate internally about major security incidents during response and investigation?

options.label: Regular transparent communication during incident response. Employees briefed on status, timeline, and findings. Reputation concerns don't suppress information sharing.
Limited communication during active response. Information shared after stabilization but some details withheld.
Minimal communication until external disclosure required. Internal information tightly restricted. 'Image management' prioritized over employee awareness.

items.evidence_required: Crisis communication plans, past incident communication records, employee survey on transparency
items.soc_mapping: Time delta between incident discovery and internal communication

items.title: Social Media Reputation Monitoring and Control
items.question: How does your organization monitor and manage social media and public discussion about security incidents?

options.label: Passive monitoring of public discussion. Focus on accurate information, not reputation control. Employees free to discuss responsibly.
Active monitoring with some narrative control. Employees told to avoid discussing incidents.
Aggressive reputation management on social media. Employees restricted from discussing incidents publicly. Image preservation prioritized.

items.evidence_required: Social media monitoring policies, employee communication guidelines, public discussion analysis
items.soc_mapping: Communication platform monitoring of incident-related discussions

items.title: Employee Personal Brand and Incident Association
items.question: How does your organization protect employee reputation when they're associated with security incidents?

options.label: Explicit protection of employee reputation. Personal brand separation from security incidents. No public identification of incident discoverers or first responders.
General awareness that incidents affect reputation but no formal protection mechanisms.
Employees often publicly associated with incidents. Fear of personal reputation damage influences incident handling decisions.

items.evidence_required: Employee protection policies, past incident disclosure patterns, internal reputation impact assessment
items.soc_mapping: Public disclosure patterns showing employee identification

items.title: Threat Response Transparency and Executive Accountability
items.question: Are executives held accountable for threat response decisions and timing with the same visibility as incident discoverers?

options.label: Executive accountability equal to employee accountability for incident response. Decisions reviewed transparently. Reputational consequences balanced across levels.
Some executive review but generally less visible accountability than for employees. Blame distribution uneven.
Executives insulated from reputation damage while employees bear consequences. Decision-making authority and accountability separated.

items.evidence_required: Post-incident review processes, executive accountability documentation, organizational response patterns
items.soc_mapping: Escalation timing and management notification delays

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Tell me about the last time someone discovered a significant security incident or breach in your organization. What was their experience?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific positive example showing rapid non-punitive reporting, full protection from consequences, documented blameless response, and no reputational damage to discoverer
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed experience with some support but also some concern about consequences or blame assignment
scoring_guidance.red: Negative outcome with blame assigned to discoverer, career consequences, or discouragement from future reporting

followups.text: What happened to the person who discovered it? Did they face any career consequences?
Did the incident response focus on prevention or on assigning blame?

items.text: What concerns do employees have about reporting security incidents? What are they worried about?

scoring_guidance.green: Employees report no significant concerns about reporting. No career risk perception. Clear understanding of protection.
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some employees express concern about consequences but organization claims to protect them
scoring_guidance.red: Clear evidence that employees fear career consequences, reputational damage, or public identification with incidents

followups.text: Do employees worry about how incident reporting affects their personal reputation or career trajectory?
Have you ever had employees delay reporting incidents to avoid consequences?

items.text: How does your organization balance security transparency with protecting organizational image when major incidents occur?

scoring_guidance.green: Transparency prioritized over image. Incidents disclosed honestly. Organization reputation tied to quality of response, not incident avoidance.
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some transparency but image protection is consideration. Selective disclosure of incident details.
scoring_guidance.red: Image protection clearly prioritized. Incidents minimized, hidden, or disclosed only when legally required.

followups.text: Walk me through your most recent significant security incident and what was disclosed publicly vs. internally.
Who makes decisions about what to disclose - security teams or legal/communications?

items.text: How much internal discussion happens during active incident response, versus after resolution when narrative can be controlled?

scoring_guidance.green: Transparent ongoing communication during active response. Employees briefed regularly regardless of how it affects image.
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some communication but careful messaging during active phase with more details after stabilization
scoring_guidance.red: Minimal communication during response. Information tightly controlled. Full disclosure delayed until narrative managed.

followups.text: Show me your timeline for a recent incident - when did discovery occur versus when was staff notified versus public disclosure?
Does security team control incident communication or does PR/legal review everything?

items.text: When incidents occur, how does accountability flow through your organization?

scoring_guidance.green: Accountability distributed across systems and decisions. Focus on prevention, not individual blame. Executive accountability visible.
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mix of systemic and individual accountability but uneven distribution by level
scoring_guidance.red: Blame concentrated on lowest-ranking staff. Executives insulated. Fear of consequences suppresses upward reporting.

followups.text: In your last three incidents, who specifically was held accountable and how were they affected?
Are executives ever held accountable for slow response times or poor incident decisions?

items.text: What protection do employees have if they report incidents anonymously versus identifying themselves?

scoring_guidance.green: Robust anonymous reporting options with verified confidentiality. Same protection whether identified or anonymous.
scoring_guidance.yellow: Anonymous options exist but confidentiality isn't guaranteed or employees skeptical about anonymity
scoring_guidance.red: No true anonymous reporting. Employees must identify themselves or find workarounds to report safely.

followups.text: How many incidents in the last year came through anonymous versus identified reporting channels?
Do employees trust that anonymous reports are truly confidential, or do they worry about identification?

items.text: How does your organization protect employees from having their personal reputation damaged by incident association?

scoring_guidance.green: Explicit policies protecting personal reputation. Incidents separated from individual performance. No public identification of discoverers.
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness but no formal protection mechanisms. Some risk of personal reputation impact.
scoring_guidance.red: Employees publicly associated with incidents. Fear of personal reputation damage influences how incidents are handled.

followups.text: In external communications about breaches, are the employees who discovered them identified or remain anonymous?
Have employees ever mentioned concern about their professional reputation if they're associated with a discovered incident?

solutions.title: Blameless Incident Response Culture
solutions.description: Establish and institutionalize blameless post-incident review processes that focus on prevention rather than blame assignment
solutions.implementation: Implement formal blameless postmortem procedures, train all incident response participants, establish clear non-retaliation policies, separate incident investigation from performance reviews, publish findings without identifying discoverers.
solutions.technical_controls: Incident tracking system with anonymization, postmortem documentation templates, feedback loops without individual identification
solutions.timeline: 30 days initial rollout, ongoing cultural reinforcement

solutions.title: Anonymous Reporting Infrastructure
solutions.description: Deploy robust anonymous incident reporting channels with verified confidentiality protection
solutions.implementation: Implement anonymous reporting platform (third-party preferred), establish confidentiality guarantees, verify anonymity, train employees on anonymous reporting, measure utilization, establish protected escalation paths.
solutions.technical_controls: Anonymous reporting portal, confidentiality enforcement, escalation without identifier exposure, regular anonymity verification testing

solutions.title: Security-First Crisis Communication
solutions.description: Establish crisis communication protocols that prioritize security transparency over image management
solutions.implementation: Develop communication policies that mandate transparent incident disclosure, establish clear decision authority, shift from legal-controlled narrative to security-focused communication, brief employees continuously during response, document communication decisions.
solutions.technical_controls: Crisis communication framework, communication tracking, incident timeline transparency dashboard, decision log

solutions.title: Executive Accountability Framework
solutions.description: Establish balanced accountability structures ensuring executives face same reputation consequences as discoverers for response failures
solutions.implementation: Create transparent escalation procedures with executive visibility, establish leadership accountability for response delays, document decision authority, measure executive performance on incident handling, tie compensation to response quality metrics.
solutions.technical_controls: Response metrics dashboard with executive visibility, decision tracking, accountability reporting

solutions.title: Employee Reputation Protection Program
solutions.description: Establish explicit policies and practices protecting employee personal reputation when associated with incident discovery
solutions.implementation: Develop employee protection policies, anonymize public disclosures, establish personal brand separation from incidents, create recognition programs for responsible disclosure, monitor and prevent internal blame culture.
solutions.technical_controls: Public disclosure anonymization procedures, employee recognition tracking, external communication monitoring

solutions.title: Training on Reputation Threat Recognition
solutions.description: Comprehensive training on recognizing when attackers are exploiting reputation concerns to suppress security responses
solutions.implementation: Training covering how attackers use reputation threats to maintain access, psychological basis for defensive behaviors, recognition of concealment pressure, reporting procedures that protect reputation, case studies of reputation-suppressed breaches.
solutions.technical_controls: Learning management system tracking, competency assessments, simulation testing with reputation pressure scenarios

risk_scenarios.title: Reputation-Suppressed Breach Discovery Delay
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers maintain access for extended periods because employees fear that reporting incidents will damage their professional reputation or create career consequences
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Subtle compromise that doesn't immediately impact operations. Employee discovers suspicious activity but delays reporting due to fear that discovering the breach will be attributed to their negligence.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Reputation threat activates amygdala and anterior insula, creating avoidance behavior. Fear of personal blame suppresses protective disclosure longer than rational analysis would predict.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: 2022 incident: 87-day detection delay when employee discovered unauthorized access but suppressed reporting due to fear of being blamed for the vulnerability that allowed compromise

risk_scenarios.title: Evidence Destruction Under Reputation Pressure
risk_scenarios.description: Employees or managers suppress incident evidence, delete logs, or destroy documentation to hide the incident and prevent reputation damage
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: After discovering incident, employee or manager deletes logs, suspends email retention, disables audit trails, or purges evidence to prevent discovery by auditors or executives
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: High reputation threat creates desperate damage control behavior. Concealment appears safer than admission, especially if previous incidents resulted in blame assignment.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: 2021 incident: Manager deleted incident logs immediately after discovering compromise, attempting to suppress evidence and prevent notification of executives

risk_scenarios.title: Authority-Based Reputation Suppression
risk_scenarios.description: Executives or authority figures suppress incident reporting by emphasizing organizational reputation damage and career consequences for discoverers
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Executive explicitly directs employees not to report incidents to protect organizational image. Uses authority position to enforce suppression.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Convergent vulnerability: Authority compliance (1.3) + Reputation threat (3.10) + Urgency pressure (2.1) creates 360%+ increased suppression probability
risk_scenarios.historical_example: 2019 incident: Executive directed team not to report unauthorized data access to preserve IPO reputation, maintaining access for 91 days

risk_scenarios.title: Blame Cascading and Blame Avoidance
risk_scenarios.description: Fear that discovering incidents will result in blame assignment creates cascade where employees blame others, hide contributions, or create false explanations to avoid reputation damage
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: After incident discovery, employees provide false explanations, blame others, or hide their involvement to avoid personal responsibility and reputation damage
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Reputation threat creates defensive attribution bias. Employees focus on impression management rather than accurate incident assessment.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: 2020 incident: Three employees provided contradictory explanations about compromised credentials, each attempting to avoid blame, delaying accurate understanding of attack chain
